author: Eric_Botswana
title: Dig it, man
review: I'm very proud to be the first to review this as this was the first Lego set I ever got. For its size and presumed cost it was quite a good set, featuring a minifig with a removable safety vest and articulated loader element. Also, being in Australia I could move the steering wheel to the other side. Giving it a 5. Obviously sentimental reasons have something to do with it but it's hard to fault anyway.

author: Mawich
title: The set that started it all...
review:
I'm 99.99% sure this was the very first Town themed set I ever received.  My parents had previously purchased set 50 (Basic Building Set) for my brother and I, but set 607 marked the beginning of what was to become a life long (with a few dark ages thrown in) interest in Lego Town. 

The Town theme at the time was essentially divided into three price points: Sets that kids could purchase with their pocket money such as this one, larger sets that kids could purchase if they saved a bit for it and the largest sets such as Fire and Police stations that required the purchasing power of parents and relations.

The set came with a few pieces which were rarely if ever seen again as the workers vest and the shovel but the rest of the set was pretty standard.  It wasn't particularly useful as a loader simply because the shovel couldn't be lifted above the height of the side of a dump truck but it was gainfully employed as a clearer of debris on streets in the town I had as a kid.

Though this set may appear overly simplistic compared to the modern City range, it has a simplistic charm about it that is common with many of the smaller sets from that era.

author: jmupton2000
title: My First Ever Set...
review:
This was my first ever set way back in 1979 and somehow managed to avoid being broken up all that time.  It's a classic example of simple, fun, low cost little sets that these days are catered for by Polybags in the same 'pocket money' price bracket.

I have as a result collected dumper trucks in the Legoland/Town/City range ever since right up and including the most recent included in Set 60184 released in 2018.

Box/Instructions:

If I am correct, the box was a fairly small one and many sets of this price bracket and era came in similarly sized boxes.  The instruction leaflet is one of the long fold out double sided sheets with seven building stages on one side whilst the other features a general view of various Town theme sets of the time (many of them now regarded rightly as classics) on a large number of the old style 32x32 road boards.  In addition a number of featured products are highlighted including the road board packs and the workshop/garage set 361.

Parts:

Just twenty three parts made up the set including the classic metal axle fitted 2x2 plates with red hubs, the hinged yellow bucket part and of course the minifigure himself.

Minifigure:

The minifigure does not really get any more classic Lego Town/City than this chap here who wears the traditional red safety helmet, classic smiley face head, plain blue torso and black legs.  The vest part (long since out of production sadly) is in yellow and had black/yellow warning stripe stickers supplied to fit both front and back although the box picture seems to indicate these were also issued as a preprinted part rather than applied with a sticker.

The Build:

Not much to it really, a set of wheels/axles fitted to a few plates with a steering wheel and a few bricks on top plus the hinged bucket on the front and that is about it.

The Completed Model:

The finished model and its accompanying minifigure was a nice little simple vehicle with lots of playability at a very reasonable price.  Many a Lego fan seems to have started with this set and a number or related construction vehicles of the same period.

Overall Conclusions:

A classic little set that still looks good even now.  Mine is still in one piece although its minifigure looks decidedly worn now, his hands have faded, he had to have his legs replaced in about 1983 after a nasty accident and the stickers on the vest are very grubby and worn.

Even if I ever disposed of all my Lego, this is the one set I would still keep.
